title: 108_hr2732
content: The Act may be cited as the "Home School Non-Discrimination Act of 2003". The Congress recognizes the established principle of parents' right to direct their children's education under the Constitution. They have affirmed this right through legislative, executive, and judicial functions. Home education has proven effective for academic success and socialization skills. Home-educated youth are successful in post-secondary education and the workforce, contributing positively to education in the US. Several laws regarding private home education need clarification on how they treat students educated at home according to State law. The US Constitution prohibits Federal control over homeschooling. The Congress recognizes private home education as a positive contribution to the US and supports parents who choose this alternative education within the Constitution. Amendments are made to clarify institutional and student eligibility under the Higher Education Act of 1965. Clarification of the child find process under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act clarifies the child find process. Section 614(a)(1) is amended to state that in cases where consent is absent for an initial evaluation or special education services, the local educational agency is not required to convene an IEP meeting or develop an IEP for the child, and will not be in violation of any requirements under this part. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act clarifies that if consent is not given for an initial evaluation or special education services, the local educational agency is not required to hold an IEP meeting or develop an IEP for the child. SEC. 6 clarifies that expenses associated with students privately educated at home under State law can be covered by the Coverdell Education Savings Account. It includes a special rule for home schools to be treated as a private school for tax purposes. The amendment applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7 clarifies publicly held records of students privately educated at home under State law. Section 444 of the General Education Provisions Act (20 U.S.C. 1232g) is amended to require written consent from parents for releasing directory information of students in non-public education, including those educated at home or in private schools according to State law. This amendment also includes non-public school students and clarifies that educational agencies are not obligated to maintain education records for these students. The General Education Provisions Act is amended to require parental consent for releasing directory information of non-public school students, including those educated at home or in private schools. Educational agencies are not required to maintain education records for these students. Additionally, organizations conducting studies for educational purposes must ensure student and parent information remains confidential. Educational organizations must destroy information when no longer needed and cannot release educational records without parental consent for non-public school students. SEC. 8 amends the Higher Education Act to include homeschooled students in the Robert C. Byrd Honors Scholarship Program. SEC. 9 clarifies the Fair Labor Standards Act for homeschooled students. The Fair Labor Standards Act is amended to extend permissible employment hours for homeschooled students aged fourteen to sixteen beyond those of traditional public school students.
